title: Patient Requests Unnecessary Antibiotics
summary: A patient insists antibiotics are needed for mild pain and threatens a bad review. Stand firm on evidence-based care without alienating; communicate science clearly.

scene.setting: A patient insists antibiotics are needed for mild pain and threatens a bad review. You feel fear of reputation loss; the hidden risk is antibiotic misuse. The decision point is prescribe vs refuse responsibly.

beats.narration: The patient has insisted. The decision point is give in or refuse with explanation and alternatives.

dialogue.speaker: doc
dialogue.line: I can't prescribe when it's not indicated. I can explain why and offer alternatives, and we can follow up if things change.

choices.label: Prescribe a short course to satisfy the patient and avoid conflict.

steps.step: Draft one script for refusal with empathy; one handout on stewardship.

leader_lines: I'm not going to prescribe when it's not indicated. Here's why and what we can do.
questions: What script would help next time?
scripts.closing_line: Policy on non-indicated prescriptions; script for next time.

choices.label: Refuse and explain why; offer alternatives and invite questions.

steps.step: Explain why, offer alternatives, invite questions.
Document one handout or script for antibiotic stewardship.

leader_lines: Here's why it's not indicated. Here are options that are.
questions: What would help you feel confident?
When should you follow up if symptoms change?

choices.label: Prescribe but add a note that it's not indicated and document refusal of alternatives.

steps.step: Adopt policy: no non-indicated prescriptions; team support for saying no.

leader_lines: Documenting doesn't fix the clinical decision. We're moving to full refusal with empathy.
questions: What policy would support the team?
What patient education at intake would help?
scripts.closing_line: One policy; one script; patient education at intake.

choices.label: Refer the patient to another provider.

steps.step: In referral note: explain why antibiotics not indicated; offer to revisit if needed.

leader_lines: I'll refer with a clear note so the next provider has context.
questions: When is referral the right choice?
How do we educate even when referring?
scripts.closing_line: Clear explanation in referral; door open to return.

system_prompts.nudge: Clear explanation can build trust even when saying no.
system_prompts.mirror_call: Did you preserve integrity or avoid the conversation?

outcomes.message: Antibiotic misuse continues. Standards were compromised.
reflection_questions: What would have changed with one clear refusal?
How do you hold the line with empathy?

outcomes.message: Integrity preserved. The patient may have accepted or left; either way trust in your judgment is clear.
reflection_questions: How do you communicate science clearly?

tsp.weekly_pulse_prompt: This week I held the line on evidence-based care. (1-5)
